name: A poor AA in a dungeon.
author: grom56

posts.author: grom56
posts.content:
I'm taking a measure of bravery from Stag and gonna toss out my first silly question to you all.  

Here's the thing, I like the idea of playing an AA, I have one running in WoG now as a matter of fact, but I keep finding myself passing over poor Amberdane whenever I suit up for a solo run.  The guy is in pretty good shape and does a really nice job soloing wilderness areas and the like, areas where he has room to move and use his called shot (leg).  But I can't seem to get myself to take him into a dungeon, it's silly I know, but all those hallways and small rooms, just seem to defeat me.   I guess I should give the class break down for him:  AA/WIZ/Fighter  8/7/4 at this point.  Was planning on ending at 26/11/4.  I'm hoping that someone here can give me a few tips to settle my nerves about taking him into tight spaces.   Can an AA do well, soloing dungeons?

Thanks for reading....

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
Hi grom,

I don't think it a silly question at all. I've just completed my first run-through as an AA (in Aielund), and the hardest thing I found to manage was exactly what you describe. It would have been agonising as a soloist, but chucking a tank in as doorway/corridor blocker made life so much easier. Nonetheless, PBS, Rapid Shot, Imbue and Hail of Arrows I found particularly useful at relatively low levels. In a solo run, I'd think the stealth skills would be particularly helpful in sniping, nipping around the corner and getting into shadows - not that they're much use for the build you're currently playing, I'm afraid. Throwing in a casting of darkness would also help confuse indoor opponents I guess.

Anyway, I'm far from an AA expert. Have you read Mick Dagger's excellent Guide to the class? It's in the Game Guides section and very informative it is, too. If you have some time on your hands, you could also have a glance at my Arcane Archer - A First Stab thread in the Unfinished Builds / Build Request forum. I'm not blowing my own trumpet here, it includes contributions from those who do know what they're talking about.

Cheers

EDIT: Sorry, grom - and to be fair, you did say you built on the hoof, but your intention of finishing at AA26/Wiz11/F4 seems to sum to 41 levels...

I haven't got Hail of Arrows yet, but I do use Imbue quite often.  It's a lot of fun to use.   I'm going to try to get my guy hunting in a major cave area on WoG soon, maybe this weekend...   I'll let you know how it goes.  I read both your build and Mick Dagger's Guild and they both gave me some ideas.

Now, I know I'm not a builder, but reading over your "First Stab" brought up a few questions and gave me an idea for my next AA toon.  My first question has more to do with something I've seen in a few different builds here, and that I just have no clue what's going on:  In your listing of your skills, you have Heal: 1 (0).  Two things about this I don't follow, what's with the second number and why have the skill if it's dropped somehow to "0"??  

My second question is about your Wizard levels.  I'm not understanding why you only take two levels?  A third level opens up another level of spells, which I would feel to be very handy to have.  This may be because of the Monk levels, I confess that I've never run a Monk, so have no clue about that.  But if you only need a single level of Wizard to open AA, why take the second level at all?  I must say I'm lost.   I found it very hard to keep my Wizard levels at no more then 11 and really would feel any less to really hurt in the long run.

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
I'll try to answer as best I can, but please bear in mind "these views do not necessarily reflect the position of the Guild". Disclaimer over.

On the skills question: that used to bamboozle me, too, but the convention is that the first figure denotes the input into the skill - in this case, just the 1 point - while the one in parenthesis shows the nett result, in this case, and with a -1 WIS, that means 0. Again, for this particular example a single inputted point in any skill is really neither here nor there, so I whacked it in Heal, otherwise I'd be left with a spare point and I don't like danglers much.

On the Wizard issue, it's quite simple. I don't do arcanists (a mixture of personal preference and lack of experience), so initially I only wanted a single Wiz level - just to qualify for AA: the second A being of greater importance to me. Not once did I cast a single spell while playing up to level 37. I ended up taking 2 levels for +1 BAB. That's because you can only take a max of 10 levels of AA pre-epic, so would initially have been left with 9 levels of Monk and 1 of Wiz. Monk is a 3/4 BAB class and Wiz a 1/2 class: which meant I'd have a BAB of 10 (AA) + 6 (Monk) + 0 (Wiz) = 16 pre-epic. Taking the second level of Wiz and dropping one of Monk gave the result of BAB 10 (AA) +6 (Monk) +1 (Wiz) = 17, thus a better chance to actually hit my target.

On reflection, I think I'd take Rogue instead of Monk myself, but Monk is my single favourite class, so when constructing that build - which was me venturing into unknown territory (should really have called it "First Shot", I suppose) - I reverted to a class I was comfortable with. I would have gone with Bard instead of Wizard (I tend not to regard Bardsong as "true" arcanism) except for two things. First, Bard is a non-Lawful class, while Monk has to be Lawful. Second, I was playing as an elf, which has Wiz as its favoured class, so I'd attract an xp penalty by taking Bard. That matters less in a PW - where you can nullify the effect by having respawning foes popping up constantly - than it does in module play, where you can't, and it can actually set you back a couple of levels or more.

There you go - hope this makes sense!

Cheers

EDIT: Sorry, meant to mention, Empyre posted his Persuasive Archer build within the First Stab thread, and that's a Rogue/AA/Wiz build which might appeal to you.

posts.author: conlaoch
posts.content:
Grom...

ya said you have wiz 7? Wiz 7 gets ya lvl 4 spells....

so any and all of the below will slow things down to give you more time to shoot em... not all are area of effect... so make sure ya know what it will do before ya get overrun...

1st lvl
Grease, Color Spray, Scare, Sleep

2nd lvl
Blindness, Darkness, Web

3rd lvl
Slow, Stinking cloud

4th lvl:
confusion, Fear, Wall of Fire

And then there are the manual things....
Bags of tanglefoot, bags of spikes, choking powder...


And I forgot to mention some of my all time favorites...

Summon Meat Shield Lvl 1-4.

Also useful for more caster heavy variations of toons as well....
